title: Quiz 9: Reliability & Validity
description: Quality assurance, threats to validity, and pilot studies.

questions.question: What is 'Internal Validity'?

options.text: Degree to which results can be generalized
Degree to which extraneous variables are controlled

questions.explanation: Internal validity is the degree to which extraneous variables are controlled.
questions.hint: Think about control within the study.

questions.question: Match the threat to validity with its description.

pairs.right: External events occurring during the study

questions.explanation: History is external events, Maturation is natural changes, Attrition is dropout, Instrumentation is tool unreliability.
questions.hint: Think about what each threat affects.

questions.question: Which of the following are methods to assess Reliability? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Test-Retest, Split-Half, and Equivalent Form assess reliability. Predictive Validity assesses validity.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ effect occurs when subjects perform better simply because they know they are being observed.
questions.explanation: The Hawthorne effect is when subjects improve due to observation.
questions.hint: Think about the effect of being watched.

questions.question: A Pilot Study should be conducted using the same subjects that will be used in the main study.
questions.explanation: Subjects in the pilot study should be similar to, but NOT the same as, those in the main study.
questions.hint: Pilot subjects should be similar, not identical.

questions.question: What does 'Construct Validity' measure?

options.text: If the tool looks like it measures what it should
If the tool covers the content domain
If the tool measures a theoretical concept/trait
If the tool predicts future behavior

questions.explanation: Construct validity measures if the tool measures a theoretical concept.

questions.question: Match the research effect to its description.

pairs.right: Control group works harder to compete
Subjects perform better due to researcher expectations

questions.explanation: Placebo is psychological improvement, John Henry is competition, Pygmalion is researcher expectations, Halo is impression bias.
questions.hint: Think about psychological biases in research.

questions.question: What type of validity involves comparing a new instrument against an established standard (criterion)?
questions.explanation: Criterion-related validity compares against a standard.
questions.hint: Think about comparing to a gold standard.

questions.question: Statistical regression is a threat to validity where extreme scores tend to:

options.text: Move towards the mean on retesting

questions.explanation: Statistical regression causes extreme scores to move toward the mean.
questions.hint: Think about scores naturally moving to average.

questions.question: Random error affects reliability, while systematic error affects validity.
questions.explanation: Random error affects consistency (reliability), systematic error affects accuracy (validity).
questions.hint: Random is inconsistent, systematic is biased.
